text: protocol to escort his Serene highness
the assembly will hear an address by his
Excellency Gabriel boric font president
of the Republic of Chile a request
protocol to escort his Excellency
on behalf of the general assembly I have
the honor to welcome his Excellency
Gabriel boric font the president of the
Republic of Chile and to invite him to
address the assembly
Mr President
distinguished representatives of the
member states of the United Nations
we have the firm conviction that
democracy
is memory and future and that's why in
our country nine days ago we
commemorated 50 years since the coup
d'etat of the 11th of September 1973
which
violently split our coexistence bringing
death persecution pain and misery to my
nation
the images of the presidential Palace La
moneda being bombed
the immolation of the Democratic elected
president of the country Mr Salvador
Allende and the self-evident truth that
the then U.S government headed by
President Nixon had conspired from the
outset to promote the downfall of the
Chilean government
touched the Democratic conscience of The
Wider world
while some countries
at that time
were betting on instability of
fragile and more robust democracies they
were International
organizations such as the U.N itself
who played a fundamental role in
defending human rights
and democracy
because from the very outset
they put it on the line to defend those
who were suffering most who were most
vulnerable in Latin America and Chile
and throughout the world
that is why
United Nations and several of the
countries here today
we have a great debt of gratitude to you
there were thousands Who provided
support to the persecuted who saved
lives and who showed solidarity which up
to today we continue to commemorate
on behalf of the victims of the Peniche
regime
since then my country has covered a
great distance we've come a long way as
Chilean citizens we feel proud
that we have come together to recover
our democracy restore our Republic and
return to the path of Human Rights and
fundamental freedoms which had been
founded by the founding fathers of our
democracy
Chile is a country which loves and
promotes peace that is our identity and
that is what we
choose to carry forward
50 years after the tragedy which I've
just outlined we have borne our pain and
we have done so via initiatives such as
the Redditch and the valik commissions
and the search committee
but at the same time
Chile remains a country which is
progressing because we've learned from
the lessons of the past
we have
analyzed our past to build a better
future and it's through that learning
that we can project ourselves into we
can see into the challenges of the
future
one of those challenges
where there is great agreement having
listened to the speeches which came
before mine is that the problems of
democracy must be solved with more and
never less democracy
is never inevitable democracy always
offers alternatives
we've also learned that human rights are
an irenouncable ethical basis in
politics and that human rights
are of no individual party and must be
defended in all places at all times
whatever the political color of the
government which undermines them that is
a principle which we have upheld and
will continue to uphold in particular as
a member of the Human Rights Council
we have learned
through our history
that democracy is vulnerable fragile
that it is not guaranteed forever and
therefore we must look out for it
that violence
is not acceptable as a method of
political action in democracy that
dialogue must always be the priority
amongst those who have different views
and that applies also to relations
between states
that is why I want to reiterate Chile's
profound conviction and commitment to
multilateralism and peaceful mechanisms
for resolving conflicts
we have also learned and I think it is
important to highlight this at times of
polarization that when we manage to come
together around shared goals we can make
progress in a shared and plural way to
the benefits of all of our peoples
because it's true to say
and you just have to follow the debates
in my country to realize this it's true
that there are major differences of
opinion in Chile today but there are
also major consensuses
and taken together
along with the four expert former
presidents who are currently still alive
we have signed a firm commitment for the
future of democracy and human rights in
our country and we invite other
State leaders to join us in this effort
even at the moment of most political
turmoil
we are able to come together to seek
ways
out of our difficulties and which put
our people ahead of our legitimate
differences
that is why together
and I underscore This Together both the
government and the opposition are
seeking paths forward to meet the
demands of our people
the generations which came before us
ladies and gentlemen assumed the
responsibility of making our Nations
independent of building Democratic
institutions and creating leadership and
Universal human rights and progressively
moving forward on achieving social
rights
My Generation which hadn't yet been born
when the coup d'etat happened in 1973 it
falls to us
to consolidate and to enhance many of
the achievements of the past at the same
time as with optimism we tackle new
threats and challenges ahead
Mr President
distinguished members of the general
assembly today there are three urgent
tasks which I humbly today wish to bring
to your attention in which my country
thinks deserve our priority and which
have already been mentioned by many in
this General Assembly today it is an
urgent task this is number one that we
look out for democracy that we take care
of it we must put a stop to the advance
of totalitarianism we must
be decisive in confronting
disinformation which is corroding our
democracies from the inside we must do
it from an Institutional and non and and
clear way we must defend the rights of
minorities but also of those who are not
minorities who are in fact the majority
such as women whose progress is
threatened by by
various forms of totalitarianism and
fanaticism
we must
tackle the profound causes that are
undermining our democracies we are
concerns
that these vulnerabilities or the loss
of democracy
democracy
will take on new forms not of the credit
as of the 20th century but new forms in
the 21st century some of which may even
have the sheen of majority to them
democracy today is not satisfying all of
the yearnings of people who urgently
want and need security greater equality
are we out of poverty democracy must be
able to come up with results we must
pour all of our efforts into that when
institutions fail or are too slow in
coming up with results corruption and
organized crime
various forms of inequality all of these
challenges which are corroding our
institutions leads to a lack of trust
among the people
that is why ladies and gentlemen looking
after democracy means tackling the
frustrations and the yearnings and the
needs of our people
we have to channel them we have to
channel them through the challenges
which we face and make progress with
shared action greater Freedom more
Prosperity Social Justice sustainability
we must always put the collective
interest ahead of individual interests
and in particular of the individual
interests of those who have the most
power including ourselves as the
governing class
in this regard
we also call for the strict respect of
human rights as our path into the a path
forward regardless of who is in
government and as I've already said in
other International fora I feel the
obligation to denounce in front of this
assembly and the world the persecution
that is brought against all those who
who have any different thoughts or ideas
than those of the government of Mr
Ortega in Nicaragua who's not only
impeding involvement in elections but is
removing citizenship
imposing house arrest and removing
political rights at the same time ladies
and gentlemen we have to come together
to reflect
on the fact that any solution to all of
these problems must
must
arrive via multilateral consensus and we
must understand that when unilateral
sanctions are imposed
that is not contributing towards the
solution
the case of the sanctions against
Venezuela for example from our
perspective today
are not contributing to improving the
life circumstances of the population of
Venezuela and we are convinced that to
ensure that there are free elections
with all the necessary safeguards for
all in Venezuela it is essential that
the United States lift the sanctions
which it has now imposed on Venezuela
the same applies to the sanctions which
have been in place for so very long
against Cuba I want to be very clear
declaring that Cuba is a country which
promotes terrorism is not just false it
is violent it is brutal and we would
call in the United States
to follow the line which was taken
a few years ago by the government of
Barack Obama when it took Cuba off of
that list
these sanctions hurt not the government
of Cuba but the people who don't deserve
it
at the same time
I feel obliged to raise my voice when it
comes to two conflicts which are
tearing apart
humanity and which comes us from two
different times
some of you legitimately will be
wondering why Chile wishes to discuss
conflicts which are happening in such
far-flung parts of the world it's
because Humanity as a whole is important
to us and we should not remain silent
when we see the illegal for example the
illegal occupation of Palestine and the
inability of Palestine to form its own
state and government the wall which is
enclosing is citizens
we must recognize
the right to exist of both of those
countries Palestine and Israel and that
is why at this Podium we call for the
respect of international law
a more recent conflict now where also we
see ambiguities
which tend to come out when these events
happen and we must clearly condemn
explicitly condemn the illegal Invasion
by Russia of Ukraine
on this point
it is our conviction
that
a conflict of this nature of these
characteristics
we cannot blame the invading government
the invading Nation
in any way in the same way as the
invaded nation and we are convinced that
peace can only be achieved by respecting
the territorial Integrity of Nations and
we say that as a country which is a
small or medium country which is what we
are a country from the far south of the
world and we say it because we
understand that countries such as ours
depend on international law for our
defense in potential future conflicts
today it's Ukraine and the future it
could be any of us and
in this context we can't close our eyes
or look away
we cannot be ambiguous in condemning
fought from our perspective is a war of
aggression and a legal war of aggression
at that
my second topic requiring urgent action
now where responsibility again does not
fall on all of us in the same way is the
climate change crisis
pollution and loss of biodiversity
hear the diagnostic is very clear almost
all of the leaders at this Rostrum have
spoken on this topic these are problems
of today not tomorrow in my country we
faced it with forest fires and other
disasters and we know that many of you
particularly the most vulnerable those
who have contributed at least to global
warming
are the ones who have
suffered the most the ones who have
burned the least fossil fuels are the
ones suffering the most from this
climate crisis and that is why we make a
call as we did earlier this morning at
the high level panel on this topic for
Rapid action to accelerate the
transition to change our consumption to
establish new rules which allow us to
meet these demanding challenges
in my country we've made progress in
that direction under different
governments with different leadership we
have 43 of protected Marine areas and
many many a very high percentage of uh
terrestrial protected areas we've set up
a number of protected areas and we've
also made commitments whereby at the
very latest by 2050 we will be climbing
neutral if not before
however
climate change means that we are facing
increasing and more complex challenges
right now it's a very severe drought
which despite the Rains of this year
which themselves brought problems
flooding in areas that had lost had were
no longer used to such Reigns
and we've also had forest fires
we are suffering a wide range of
phenomena which have a direct impact on
the most vulnerable
we understand that the same problems are
happening elsewhere in the world for
example the major floods recently in
Libya which the Secretary General and
the president both mentioned in their
addresses yesterday last year in
Pakistan there was
a drought in Argentina in Central in in
the Horn of African Central America
these are just a few examples which
should move us into action now
and that is why we need to do more I
would make a call
on the countries with greatest
industrial activity to assume their full
responsibility not just to be more
environmentally respectful but also to
show greatest greater solidarity with
those who are suffering most such as the
small Pacific island nations
who are suffering the effects of climate
change also Central America and the
Caribbean they are suffering the
devastating effects of climate changing
a crisis which we had
no hand in causing
in Chile we are putting all of our
weight behind
environmental agreements and making huge
efforts
since last year for example for an
agreement to protect the oceans
this year we signed the
bbnj convention and today before this
assembly I wish to reiterate our
commitment and willingness for
Valparaiso the historic gateway to
America the pearl of the Pacific to
become the headquarters of that treaty's
Secretariat you can count on us for its
proper development and to contribute
to a more sustainable and fairer more
Equitable development finally the third
challenge which I think has to be a
priority relates to technological change
which can only be compared with the
industrial revolution of the mid
19th century which will change entirely
the way that we think that we relate
that we produce that we work only a few
weeks ago we saw in a small town in
Spain how a
a few hours ago in fact a mother had to
report to the police how a group of boys
at school had taken images of her
daughter and using artificial
intelligence created pornographic images
of her daughter and distributed them the
world is changing
people have a right to privacy to their
integrity
all changes in technology throughout the
history of humanity have been a major
opportunity to create fairer societies
but if we get it wrong there can also be
sources of new
Injustice and in this context it is the
obligation of all to create multilateral
consensus to create a ethical framework
for the development and use of new
technologies such as artificial
intelligence
we need a framework which takes the
human rights perspective into account in
the research and development of new
technologies in order to protect and
ferment the dignity and the rights of
peoples and individuals
societies must make progress there can
be no doubts but we have to do it in a
responsible way
that is why understanding and better
managing opportunities of new
technologies to put it to use for our
benefit before it becomes a threat is so
important and I would concluding I would
conclude by saying that this is an
obligation
and it is what we've been doing in Chile
since the Congress on the future which I
am absolutely sure you all have
initiatives of a similar nature in your
country
with humility but with pride I can State
here today that my country
can stand as a Latin American reference
for the future of artificial
intelligence and we are going to work
tirelessly in that responsible Direction
democracy as I said is memory but it is
also future and that's why we think that
technological development has to be a
tool for Unity not division it has to
promote the impairment of all of society
we must tackle the phenomenon of
disinformation
which
is brought to bear in particular against
the most vulnerable in society we must
assure that it does not drive us further
apart both within our countries and at
the international level
I conclude by saying that the challenges
we Face require audacious and Collective
Solutions because none of us even the
most powerful country in the world can
tackle these challenges in isolation
the phenomena of the climate crisis
migration pandemics no no borders no no
Flags they affect all countries of the
world and that is why this forum this
General Assembly must
stand up to these challenges we must
rise to the occasion we must show that
we are more than just empty words and
more than the speech made yesterday by
the Secretary General Mr Antonio
guterres we must reform Global
governance both in its political aspects
as well as Financial
it is reform or the dissent into
barbarism
we stand for reform and we can tell the
Secretary General that he has our
support not just in reforming the
security Council but also the financial
institutions that were born out of the
Bretton Woods consensus
I underscore democracy is memory and
future and on the path to a better world
the role of this General Assembly
will be decisive
that is why and because we've learned
from our past
and as a representative of a new
generation
I am optimistic about what is yet to
come in our future this General Assembly
throat is more than 70 years of History
has shown that even the most difficult
times
it is possible for Humanity to strike
agreements on the path towards civilized
cooperation and coexistence
distinguished delegates you will always
be able to count on Chile to promote and
to defend human rights
multilateralism democracy and together
to build a sustainable future and a
world free of poverty which has greater
social equality thank you very much
[Applause]
on behalf of the assembly
I wish to thank the president of the
Republic of Chile for the statement just
made and I request protocol to Scotty's
excellence
the assembly will hear an address by his
